Administration.text:
Type: Osmotherapy, electrolyte/IVF
Dosage Forms:
3% (513mEq/L)
5% (856mEq/L)
23.4% (4000mEq/L)
Nebulized (as adjunct for
bronchiolitis
,
cystic fibrosis
)

Symptomatic_Hyponatremia.text: Bolus 100-250mL 3% NS 100cc bolus over 10min; repeat after 10min x1 if no improvement

Elevated_ICP.text:
Most studies used 250 mL bolus of 7.5% HTS with dextran
[1]
Initial 250mL bolus of 3% will reduce ICP and can be delivered through a peripheral line
Target Na 145-155 meq/dL

Symptomatic_Hyponatremia.text: Bolus 100-250mL 3% NS 100cc bolus over 10min; repeat after 10min x1 if no improvement

Elevated_ICP.text:
Most studies used 250 mL bolus of 7.5% HTS with dextran

Initial 250mL bolus of 3% will reduce ICP and can be delivered through a peripheral line

Initial 250mL bolus of 3% will reduce ICP and can be delivered through a peripheral line

Pediatric_Dosing.text:
Symptomatic
hyponatremia
: 2mL/kg of 3% over 10-60 minutes, repeat of up to 3 times
Elevated ICP
3% NS: 3-10 mL/kg over 10-60 minutes
[2]
Titrate to serum Na 145-150

Special_Populations.text:
Pregnancy Rating
: C
Lactation risk
: Infant risk minimal

Contraindications.text:
Allergy to class/drug
Hypernatremia
Chronic hyponatremia
Severe CHF (theoretical), volume overload

Serious.text:
Hypotension
(infusion rate-related)
Metabolic acidosis
Hypernatraemia
Hypokalemia
Volume overload
Renal failure
Coagulopathy
Phlebitis, tissue necrosis if extravasates (need central line for concentrations >3%
If Na+ corrected too quickly, central pontine myelinosis, seizure, encephalopathy

Pharmacology.text:
Half-life: rapid onset of action (~10min), effect lasts ~1hr
Metabolism:
Excretion:

See_Also.text:
Head trauma (main)
,
Pediatric head trauma
Elevated intracranial pressure
